Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Novel Data Assimilation Techniques in Mathematical Cardiology-Development, Analysis and Validation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Heart disease remains the leading cause of death in industrialized countries, including the US, where it causes 1/3 of all total deaths. Normally, the heart contracts in response to electrical waves that propagate through cardiac muscle; however, deadly arrhythmias can result when disturbances arise in these electrical waves occur and lead to irregular heart contractions. Scientific computing applied to cardiovascular problems is becoming a formidable tool (in addition to in vitro and in vivo studies) not only to understand these pathologies but also to design devices and optimize therapies. For computing simulations to be reliable and accurate in clinical settings, it is crucial that cardiac conductivities and other parameter values utilized in mathematical models are estimated carefully. Unfortunately, there is no common agreement for these parameters, and the uncertainty surrounding their values affects the reliability of quantitative analysis. In this project, we use a combined approach of mathematical methods, computing techniques and experiments to estimate accurately these parameters necessary to perform numerical simulations of cardiac tissue dynamics in normal and diseased tissue correctly. This research has the potential to elucidate arrhythmia mechanisms and to develop therapies by providing a quantified testbed for simulations. It is a truly interdisciplinary project that connects biology, physiology, physics and computation through a mathematical methodology and an integrative approach between theory, simulations and experiments. Results will be made available the public and other researchers via publications and online via TheVirtualHeart.org.

The bidomain model for electrocardiology is the accepted mathematical formalism for modeling the propagation of cardiac action potentials across tissue when including intra- and extracellular components. Numerical simulations of electrical propagation in heart tissue are extremely sensitive to the values used for the conductivity, which is described by a 3D symmetric tensor for each point in space. A precise quantification of the entries of this tensor in practice is still an open and challenging problem from both the mathematical and biological points of view. We formulate the problem of conductivity quantification as a variational inverse problem. The conductivities are regarded as the control variable for the minimization of the mismatch between the activation time computed and the one retrieved from potential measurements. The two challenges addressed by the present proposal are (i) development and analysis of specific computational methods for the solution of the inverse problem including appropriate model reduction techniques to solve the problem in real cases and (ii) extensive validation of the methods in experimental settings for different tissues within the heart, such as right and left ventricles and atria, and for different mammalian tissues. The proposed research will develop new mathematical methods and techniques for inverse problems and will advance our understanding of wave propagation in cardiac tissue for normal and diseased states. It will further allow the use of mathematical models and methods for real applications, particularly when addressing clinical problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematical and numerical modeling and scientific computing are bringing a revolution in medicine and clinics. As medical images brought at the beginning of the 20th Century a completely new perspective to the medical practice, predictive tools based on mathematical models and quantitative analyses have been changing the approach to the clinical practice since years. In order this revolution to be completed, with a great benefit for the healthcare and the society, we need mathematical methods for an accurate set-up of patient-specific models, the basic ingredient of personalized medicine. One of the key steps is the patient-specific identification of parameters featured by the mathematical models, which can generally stem from non-invasive numerical procedures that include available clinical data into the model. In this project we considered the fundamental question of estimating the cardiac conductivity of the heart tissue in an individual, starting from patient-specific measures of the potential propagation.

The cardiac conductivities are a set of parameters crucial for the mathematical description of the potential propagation. Anomalous patterns on the cardiac potential may indicate abnormal tissue (scars) that, in this way, can be detected by a data assimilation procedure with no invasive analysis for the patients. More in general, accurate quantification of cardiac conductivity is critical for surgical planning like the optimal placement of a pacemaker in a diseased human heart. It is reasonable to expect that the location of the pacemaker on the cardiac tissue could be driven by optimality criteria with a decision support mathematical tool, as a significant piece of research in computational electrophysiology has been done in this particular field. For this tool to work, it is critical to have an accurate quantification of the conductivities. Similar arguments can be used for data-driven ablation of the cardiac tissue, a surgical procedure intended to restore the normal patterns of the potential propagation by changing the physical features of the tissue locally.

In this project, we proposed a rigorous formulation to the problem of the quantification of conductivity from potential data. The approach is based on classical variational principles, applied for the first time to this problem.

A rigorous analysis of the problem has been carried out, showing under what (realistic) circumstances a solution exists.

 Optimization numerical procedures have been developed to obtain a timely quantification of the parameters. These procedures turned out to be extremely demanding regarding computational costs.  For this reason, part of the research has been devoted to the definition of surrogate models that can accelerate the identification procedure. We first investigated the role of the so-called Monodomain Inverse Conductivity Problem as a surrogate of the most complete and accurate Bidomain Inverse Conductivity Problem. Then, we explored surrogate modeling modern techniques based on the offline/online paradigm. Specifically, we investigated methods based on the Proper Orthogonal Decomposition, and the Proper Generalized Decomposition (POD and PGD respectively) approaches. While the former was applied successfully to the problem but only after a strong customization of the procedure, the latter seems to give more promising results for future developments.

In addition, an important validation was carried out for the entire mathematical framework. Starting from potential measures, we identified the conductivity parameters that we used for the computation of the potential in animal models. The computed potential was then compared with the measured one on a much larger set of available data. The results demonstrated that the data assimilation procedure does allow a reliable reconstruction of the experimental data.

The results have been disseminated on scientific journals and at several conferences (both invited and contributed). A number of Minisymposia was organized in association with International Conferences to promote the cross-pollination in the relevant communities. 

The numerical solver was developed in an Object-Oriented C++ Library (LifeV) accessible under L-GPL License at the website of the project.

The project provided support for a Ph.D. student who will successfully defend his dissertation in 2019 and inspiration for the research of another Ph.D. student (who already brilliantly got her degree) and a master student (who also got already his degree). Also, many educational initiatives for undergraduate and K-12 high school students benefitted from this research, as the application of rigorous mathematical techniques to biomedical problems is definitely a captivating topic for young students, promoting STEM disciplines.          

The project will be continued with the specific aim of improving the understanding and the clinics of pathologies related to the anomalous propagation of the potential in the cardiac tissue, and specifically to the placement of pacemakers, in collaboration with radiologists and medical doctors at Emory.
